<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 207, 280, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 248, 560, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 313, 387, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 343, 235, 356]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 600, 371]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 372, 890, 400]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 415, 890, 444]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 444, 890, 459]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 473, 555, 488]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 503, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 98, 680, 545]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 79, 168, 94]]<|/det|>
## Formulae

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 325, 310, 342]]<|/det|>

decay constant,  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 108, 570, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 160, 530, 177]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 187, 542, 216]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 225, 527, 242]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 250, 583, 281]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} < c^2 >\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 291, 540, 310]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 325, 566, 343]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 349, 600, 377]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{x_0^2 - x^2}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 380, 546, 410]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 421, 643, 440]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 453, 600, 471]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 484, 536, 507]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 518, 600, 536]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 549, 640, 568]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_1 + 1 / R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 581, 560, 599]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 612, 582, 630]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 635, 540, 670]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 520, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 275, 707, 292]]<|/det|>
\(\theta\) is determined from the corresponding values of \(X\) by using this graph.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 291, 805, 308]]<|/det|>
\(X\) is measured with a percentage uncertainty of \(\pm 1\%\) of its value at all temperatures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 322, 560, 339]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the uncertainty in \(\theta\) is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 351, 130, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 352, 564, 369]]<|/det|>
The percentage uncertainty in \(\theta\) is least near \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 379, 133, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 380, 583, 396]]<|/det|>
The percentage uncertainty in \(\theta\) is least near \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 406, 130, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 406, 520, 422]]<|/det|>
The actual uncertainty in \(\theta\) is least near \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 433, 541, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 433, 541, 450]]<|/det|>
The actual uncertainty in \(\theta\) is least near \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 477, 94, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 477, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
The measurement of a physical quantity may be subject to random errors and to systematic errors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 523, 349, 539]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 552, 813, 568]]<|/det|>
<pre>A Random errors can be reduced by taking the average of several measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 578, 763, 594]]<|/det|>
<pre>B Random errors are always caused by the person taking the measurement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 690, 620]]<|/det|>
<pre>C A systematic error cannot be reduced by adjusting the apparatus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 846, 647]]<|/det|>
<pre>D A systematic error results in a different reading each time the measurement is taken.

spacingorderingmotion
Amolecules in ice are closer together than molecules in watera regular pattern of molecules in both ice and watermolecules in both ice and water have the same average speed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 531, 461]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 477, 486]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 496, 522, 513]]<|/det|>

<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 675, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 141, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 101, 545, 119]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 136, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 127, 536, 145]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 152, 564, 170]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 717, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 179, 717, 196]]<|/det|>
